questions.text: Which zone of the prostate suggested by McNeal gives rise to carcinoma most commonly?
questions.solution:
The classification of the prostate into different zones by McNeal -

  • Peripheral zone - Lies mainly posteriorly and from which most carcinomas arise.
  • Central zone - Lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the ejaculatory ducts as they pass through the prostate; the two zones are rather like an egg in an eggcup.
  • Transitional zone - Periurethral in location. Most cases of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) arise from this zone.

MC NEAL ZONE OF ANATOMY OF PROSTATE

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 27th Edition, Chapter 78, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1456.

choices.text: Acute retention of urine is sometimes the first symptom of bladder outlet obstruction
Haematuria may be a complication of BPH
>750 ml is considered as chronic retention
Urinary infection and calculi are prone to develop

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the complications of bladder outlet obstruction?
questions.solution:
Complications of bladder outlet obstruction (BOO)-

  • Acute retention of urine is sometimes the first symptom of BOO.
  • Chronic retention- In patients whom the residual volume is ≥250mL, the tension in the bladder wall increases owing to the combination of a large volume of residual urine and increased resting and filling bladder pressures (a condition known as high-pressure chronic retention).
  • The increased intramural tension results in functional obstruction of the upper urinary tract with the development of bilateral hydronephrosis.
  • As a result, upper tract infection and renal impairment may develop.
  • Impaired bladder emptying leads to the development of a large volume of residual urine causing urinary infection and calculi to develop.
  • Haematuria- may be a complication of BPH.

BLADDER OUTLET OBSTRUCTION

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 84, Page Number 1524 & 1525.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for prostatectomy in BPH?
questions.solution:
Residual urine of 200ml or more is an indication.

Strong indications for prostatectomy include:

  • Acute retention in fit men with no other cause for retention (drugs, constipation, recent operation)
  • Chronic retention and renal impairment
    • Residual urine of 200mL or more
    • Raised blood urea
    • Hydroureter or hydronephrosis
    • Uraemic manifestations
  • Complications of bladder outflow obstruction - stone, infection and diverticulum
  • Haemorrhage - occasionally, venous bleeding from a ruptured vein overlying the prostate will require prostatectomy to be performed.
  • Elective prostatectomy for severe symptoms-
    • Increasing difficulty in micturition, with considerable frequency day and night
    • Delay in starting and a poor stream

Acute retention of urine is sometimes the first symptom of BOO. Chronic retention. In patients in whom the residual volume is >250 mL or so, the tension in the bladder wall increases owing to the combination of a large volume of residual urine and increased resting and filling bladder pressures (a condition known as high-pressure chronic retention).

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1524.

questions.text: All of the following are voiding symptoms, except?
questions.solution:
Lower urinary tract symptoms can be classified as -

High rates of ascending UTI and increased risk of malignancy (associated with mixing of faecal and urinary streams), bowel frequency and urge incontinence have limited its use.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The urinary bladder. Pg: 1519.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause bladder outlet obstruction?
questions.solution:
Vesico-ureteral reflux (VUR) does not cause bladder outlet obstruction (BOO). VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the ureter.

Urodynamically proven BOO may result from-

  • BPH - Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Bladder neck stenosis
  • Bladder neck hypertrophy
  • Prostate cancer
  • Urethral strictures
  • Functional obstruction due to neuropathic conditions

Urodynamically proven BOO may result from:

  • BPH;
  • bladder neck stenosis;
  • bladder neck dyssynergia or functional bladder neck obstruction;
  • bladder neck hypertrophy;
  • prostate cancer;
  • urethral stricture;
  • functional obstruction due to neuropathic conditions.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1524.

questions.text: A 67 years old male patient presents to emergency department with complaint of inability to void with sudden onset severe pain in lower abdomen. He had history of significant lower urinary tract symptoms. On examination below are the findings. What is the possible condition here?
questions.solution:
The image along with the history is indicative of acute urinary retention.

Treatment - Emergency catheterisation to drain the urine.

Chronic retention. In patients in whom the residual volume is >250 mL or so, the tension in the bladder wall increases owing to the combination of a large volume of residual urine and increased resting and filling bladder pressures (a condition known as high-pressure chronic retention). The increased intramural tension results in functional obstruction of the upper urinary. As a result, upper tract infection and renal impairment may develop. Such men may present with overflow incontinence, enuresis and renal insufficiency. These symptoms should alert the doctor to the presence of this condition.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1524

questions.text: All of the following are complications of TURP (Transurethral Resection of Prostate), except?
questions.solution:
Retrograde ejaculation is a complication of TURP.

Complications of TURP include -

  • Retrograde ejaculation
    • Most common complication
    • Occurs due to disruption of bladder neck
  • Erectile impotence
  • Risk of reoperation is seen in about 15% of cases after 8-10 years.
  • Severe sepsis is found in about 6% of cases.
  • Severe hematuria requiring transfusion of more than 2 units of blood occurs in about 3%.
  • Urethral stricture
  • Urinary incontinence - if external urethral sphincter is damaged
  • TURP syndrome.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1530.

choices.text: Can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatraemia and haemolysis
Incidence of this condition has been increased since the introduction of bipolar TURP
There is frequently confusion and other cerebral events
The treatment consists of fluid restriction

questions.text: Which is not true regarding TURP syndrome?
questions.solution:
Incidence of TURP syndrome has decreased since introduction of bipolar TURP.

Water intoxication is also known as TURP syndrome. It occurs due to absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral resection.

Features seen include -

  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hyponatraemia - can cause confusion
  • Haemolysis.

The treatment consists of fluid restriction.

TURP syndrome can be prevented by -

  • Using isotonic glycine for irrigating during resection.
  • Using bipolar TURP where saline is used as an irrigant.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1530.

choices.text: Endogenous calculi are usually composed of calcium phosphate
In cases associated with severe chronic prostatic infection, the associated fibrosis and nodularity are difficult to differentiate from carcinoma

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding prostatic calculi, except?
questions.solution:
Prostatic calculi usually require no treatment.

Prostatic calculi -

  • Are of two varieties -
    • Endogenous - Most common
    • Exogenous - Comparatively rare.
  • An exogenous prostatic calculus is a urinary (commonly ureteric) calculus that becomes arrested in the prostatic urethra.
  • Endogenous prostatic calculi are usually composed of calcium phosphate combined with about 20% organic material.
  • Prostatic calculi are usually symptomless.
  • In cases associated with severe chronic prostatic infection, the associated fibrosis and nodularity are difficult to differentiate from carcinoma.
  • On radiographs or ultrasound scans, these stones are often seen to form a horseshoe or a circle.
  • Usually require no treatment.

PROSTATIC CALCULI Prostatic calculi are of two varieties: endogenous, which are common, and exogenous, which are comparatively rare. An exogenous prostatic calculus is a urinary (commonly ureteric) calculus that becomes arrested in the prostatic urethra. Endogenous prostatic calculi are usually composed of calcium phosphate combined with about 20% organic material.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1532

choices.text: Metastatic disease, which may arise from a clinically evident tumour (M1)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding prostate cancer staging?
questions.solution:
In stage T1c, tumor is identified by needle biopsy.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1532-1533

questions.text: A 77 years old man with biopsy proven prostate cancer and serum PSA of 67 presents with following bone scan. What is the likely stage?
questions.solution:
Bone scan shows multiple hot-spots suggestive of metastatic disease in a man with prostate cancer.

Once the diagnosis has been established, if metastatic spread is suspected (on the basis of a high PSA [>10 ng/mL], locally advanced disease or presence of Gleason 7 or higher) a bone scan should be carried out. If, however, the PSA is <10 ng/mL, then a bone scan would be performed only on clinical indications. The bone scan is performed by the injection of technetium-99m, which is then monitored using a gamma camera. It is more sensitive in the diagnosis of metastases (Figure 84.20) than a skeletal survey, but false positives occur in areas of arthritis, osteomyelitis or a healing fracture.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1535.

choices.text: Should be carried out only in men with a life expectancy of < 10 yrs
Exclusion of metastases would be required before surgery
Results in a high incidence of impotence

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Radical prostatectomy is suitable for-

  • Localised disease
  • Carried out only in men with a life expectancy of >10 years.
  • Exclusion of metastases would require a negative bone scan and MRI of the pelvis.

Procedure -

Removal of the prostate down to the distal urethral sphincter, in addition to the seminal vesicles. The bladder neck is reconstituted and anastomosed to the urethra.

It results in a high incidence of impotence, but a low incidence of severe stress incontinence (<2%), which may require the fitting of an artificial urinary sphincter or urethral sling.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1536.

choices.text: Severe, unremitting perineal and rectal pain
Transrectal ultrasound may aid in diagnosis
Nonsurgical management with antibiotics is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Prostatic abscess -

  • Presents with temperature rising steeply with rigors, severe, unremitting perineal and rectal pain with occasional tenesmus. Can be confused with an anorectal abscess.
  • Antibiotic usage disguises these features.
  • Rectal examination - Enlarged, hot, extremely tender and fluctuant prostate.
  • Transrectal ultrasound or MRI may aid diagnosis.

Treatment -

  • The abscess should be drained without delay by perurethral resection (unroofing the whole cavity) or using a needle via the transrectal or perineal route.
  • Antibiotic therapy.
  • Suprapubic catheterisation if retention of urine present.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1537.

choices.text: Trimethoprim or ciprofloxacin penetrate well into the prostate
Metronidazole is used if the causative organism is Trichomonas
If Chlamydia is suspected, doxycycline is the antibiotic treatment of choice
Radical prostatectomy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which is not a preferable treatment option for chronic prostatitis?
questions.solution:
Chronic prostatitis -

  • Antibiotic therapy is the mainstay of treatment. Should be administered in accordance with sensitivity tests.
  • Trimethoprim or ciprofloxacin penetrate well into the prostate.
  • If Trichomonas or anaerobes are the responsible agent, a rapid response is obtained from administration of metronidazole (200 mg TDS for 7 days to both partners).
  • If Chlamydia is suspected, doxycycline is the antibiotic treatment of choice.
  • There is little evidence that prostatic massage helps in eradicating the infection.

Chronic prostatitis Many urologists find the diagnosis of chronic prostatitis and 'proctodynia' very difficult as many men present with peri genital pain, testicular pain, prostatic pain exacerbated by sexual intercourse or pain that apparently renders sexual intercourse out of the question. Psychosexual dysfunction in such patients may be the underlying problem.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 84, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1537.
